) Purpose: This Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) provides instruction for ing and resolving taxpayer cases involving a third-party payer (TPP). (
) Audience: The primary users for this IRM are Collection employees in the Small Business/Self Employed (SBSE) operating division. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Collection Policy (
) Program Owner: Collection Policy - Employment Tax Group (
) Primary Stakeholders: • Field Collection • Campus Collection (

) Program Goals: By following the processes and procedures provided in this IRM Collection employees working third-party payer cases will be able to: • Determine liability in cases involving third-party payers • Take appropriate action to address delinquencies involving third-party payers • Assist employers adversely impacted by the fraudulent activity of a third-party payer (

) This IRM section provides a summary of the different types of third-party arrangements and procedural guidance for Collection employees employment tax delinquencies involving employers and third-party payers. (

) An employer may choose to enter into an agreement with a third party in the third party performs some or all of the employer’s federal employment withholding, reporting and payment obligations. Collection issues arise when the third party fails to ﬁle returns, make deposits, or pay on behalf of the employer. (
) The liability of the employer for employment taxes may shift depending on type of third-party arrangement. (
) Liability is always determined by the provisions of the Internal Revenue (IRC or Code) and cannot be altered by a private agreement or contract between an employer (see IRM
) and a third party. (

Purpose: This Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) provides instruction for identify- ing and resolving taxpayer cases involving a third-party payer (TPP).
Program Goals: By following the processes and procedures provided in this IRM Collection employees working third-party payer cases will be able to:
Determine liability in cases involving third
party payers Take appropriate action to address delinquencies involving payers Assist employers adversely impacted by the fraudulent activity of a third

Authorities related to this section include:
Field Collecting (
) The Director, Collection Policy is responsible for the policies and within the Collection Third-Party Payer program. (
) The Collection Policy - Employment Tax Group is responsible for and delivery of policies and procedures within the program. (
) Collection employees are responsible for implementing these policies and cedures in appropriate situations involving third-party payers. (

) Program reviews are conducted on a periodic basis with the use of data the Integrated Collection System (ICS). ICS and ENTITY systems provide Management access to reports that can be used to obtain information on employment cases in general, including information on case age, case balance, case status, and timeliness of employee actions. (
) Program effectiveness is measured through periodic operational and reviews, including managerial case reviews and National Quality Review System reviews. (
) Program controls to oversee the processing of balance due and return cases involving third-party payers and their clients are found in IRM Controls
, Resource Guide for Managers, Collection Group Manager, Territory Manager and Area Director Operational Aid. (
) ICS and ENTITY systems provide resources and tools to help employees management ensure that cases are worked timely and appropriately. (
) Collection Area PSP-PEO Coordinators have been designated to facilitate sharing of information and coordination of issues involving third-party cases. (
) The Electronic Federal Tax Payment System (EFTPS) serves as a control, allowing employers to verify payments being made on their behalf authorized TPPs. (

Federal employment taxes are imposed on wages paid to employees and are comprised of the Federal Insurance Contributions Act (FICA) tax, Federal Un
employment Tax Act (FUTA) tax, and income tax withholding (ITW). The Railroad Retirement Tax Act (RRTA) imposes a tax on compensation paid to railroad employees and employee representatives.

) A common law employer is any person who has the status of employer the usual common law rules applicable in determining the relationship. (
) The existence of an employer-employee relationship generally is determined using the common law control test and is based on the facts and circum- stances of each case. (

) Generally, an employer-employee relationship exists under the common law when the person for whom the services are performed has the right to direct and control the individual who performs the services, not only as to the result to be accomplished by the work, but also as to the details and means by that result is accomplished. In other words, an employee is subject to the will and control of the employer not only as to what shall be done, but how it be done. It is not necessary that the employer actually direct or control the manner in which the services are performed; it is sufficient if the employer the right to do so. (

Behavioral control relates to facts that show whether the business has a right to direct or control how the worker performs the speciﬁc tasks for

Behavioral control relates to facts that show whether the business has a right to direct or control how the worker performs the speciﬁc tasks for which he or she is engaged, including instructions and training. Financial control relates to facts that show whether the business has a right to direct and control the ﬁnancial and business aspects of the worker’s activities, including the extent to which the worker has a signiﬁ

cant investment, unreimbursed business expenses, or may realize a proﬁt or loss, and the extent to which the worker makes his or her services available to the relevant market. Relationship of the parties relates to facts that show how the parties perceive their relationship. These facts may include the intent of the parties in establishing the relationship, written contracts, the perma
nency of the relationship, and the extent to which services performed by

parties in establishing the relationship, written contracts, the perma- nency of the relationship, and the extent to which services the worker are a key aspect of the regular business of the company. (

) A person in control of the payment of wages is commonly referred to as the “section
) employer” or the “statutory employer”. (
) A third party is the section
) employer only if it has exclusive over the payment of wages. Treasury Regulation
(f) provides the term “employer” means the person having legal control of the payment the wages. If it shares control with the common law employer, then the third party is not a section
) employer. (

) Whether or not a third party is in control of the payment of wages depends upon the facts and circumstances. Generally, the IRS considers a third party be in control of the payment of wages if the payment is not contingent upon, proximately related to, the third party having ﬁrst received funds from the employer. Conversely, if the payment of wages is contingent on, or related to, the common law employer’s transfer of funds to the third party, Service considers the common law employer to be in control of the payment wages. Thus, the common law employer remains obligated to withhold, and pay employment taxes.

) A temporary staffing service (TSS) provides workers to supplement a ﬁrm’s workforce for a short or indeﬁnite period to address conditions such as Staffing employee absences, temporary skill shortages, or seasonal workloads. Typically, a TSS recruits and, in some cases, trains workers and assigns to a ﬁrm/client on a non-permanent basis. The TSS also controls the of the workers’ wages and provides the workers with other beneﬁts. (
) Workers provided by a TSS traditionally make up only a small portion of TSS client’s workforce and usually perform services for the client for a period. (
) After a worker completes work for one client, the TSS typically reassigns workers to a different client. (

) A TSS who recruits, trains, and controls the job assignments of the and sets the workers’ wages is likely to be the common law employer of Staffing workers it provides to a client. When a TSS is the common law employer Filing workers it provides to a client, the TSS must withhold, report, and pay ment taxes consistent with its status as a common law employer. See IRM

) Even though the workers may provide services for multiple clients of the during the year, the TSS as the common law employer uses a single FICA FUTA wage base when computing taxes. (

Beginning with tax year 2010, a section 3504 agent ﬁling an aggregate Form 941 on behalf of one or more employers must attach a Schedule R (Form 941), Allocation Schedule for Aggregate Form 941 Filers, to the Form 941. An employer should ensure its PSP is using EFTPS so the employer can conﬁrm payments are being made on its behalf. An employer can register the EFTPS system to get its own PIN and use this PIN to periodically verify payments. On January

, EFTPS began issuing Inquiry PINs to new clients of payroll service batch providers if the batch provider client was not already enrolled in EFTPS. An Inquiry PIN allows an employer without an EFTPS account to monitor EFTPS payment submissions made on their by a payroll service provider. A “red ﬂag” should arise the ﬁrst time a payroll service provider misses or makes a late payment. When an employer registers on EFTPS, it will have on-line access to its payment history for

months. In addition, registering on EFTPS allows an employer to make tax payments its third-party payer is not authorized to on its behalf, such as estimated tax payments and FTDs for returns or not included in the PSP-employer arrangement.

When an employer registers on EFTPS, it will have on-line access to its payment history for 16 months. ) Penalty relief may not be appropriate in all cases. Under no circumstances may interest be removed for reasonable cause. Some factors to consider in evaluating penalty abatement requests in these types of cases are: • The employer had sufficient funds available to pay the taxes at the due, and the third-party payer timely received or debited the funds. • The period of time during which the employer was unable to comply with the law due to circumstances beyond the employer’s control. • The timeliness of the employer’s corrective actions, once the had actual knowledge of the tax problem(s). • The source of the ﬁnancial problem(s) has been removed (such as third-party payer has been replaced), and recent compliance clearly demonstrates the tax problem(s) was(were) solely the result of the party payer’s actions. • Documentation supports the facts and circumstances presented by employer. (
) In certain circumstances where the employer has been harmed by its third- party payer, additional factors to consider for meeting reasonable cause include:
